Introduction

During vaginal delivery, pressure from the fetal head and maternal pushing causes vaginal, labial, and perineal edema.  The vagina and labia, which are relatively elastic, can stretch to accommodate vaginal delivery.  The perineum is less elastic and more likely to lacerate; these lacerations are classified based on the structures involved, which determines management and prognosis.

Anatomy of the female perineum

Structures



The perineum separates the vagina and anus.  Anteriorly, the vaginal orifice is surrounded by the bulbospongiosus muscle, making it the most likely perineal muscle to be injured because it is the most anterior.  Posteriorly, the anal orifice is surrounded by the external and internal anal sphincter muscles (ie, anal sphincter complex), which are at risk for injury with deep lacerations.



At the center of the perineum is the perineal body, which serves as an anchor point for multiple superficial pelvic floor muscles and consists of muscular, fascial, and fibrous components (

figure 1
).  The structures forming and attaching to the perineal body include :



  • Bulbospongiosus (bulbocavernosus) muscle, anteriorly
  • Superficial transverse perineal muscle, laterally
  • Fibers from the external anal sphincter muscle, posteriorly


Perineal lacerations occur in the midline of the perineal body, where the components join and the structure is weakest.

Vascular supply



  • Internal pudendal artery (predominant) is a branch off the internal iliac artery that travels with the pudendal nerve through the pudendal canal to supply the perineum.
  • Perineal arteries are small branches off the internal pudendal artery.

Innervation



The pudendal nerve originates from the S2-S4 nerve roots and passes between the piriformis and coccygeus muscles as it exits the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen.  It then reenters the pelvis through the lesser sciatic foramen and takes a curved course around the ischial spines before dividing into:



  • Sensory branches to the external genitalia, perineum, and perianal area
  • Motor branches to the perineal muscles and external urethral and anal sphincters

Risk factors



Risk factors for perineal laceration include primiparity and excessive force against the perineum during labor and delivery (eg, prolonged second stage of labor, fetal macrosomia).  A significant risk factor, particularly for deeper lacerations, is operative vaginal delivery (eg, forceps).

Classification



Perineal lacerations are classified based on depth and anatomic structures involved (

figure 2
).



  • First-degree:  involves the vaginal mucosa and perineal skin.
  • Second-degree:  extends to and involves the perineal muscles (eg, bulbospongiosus).
  • Third-degree:  extends beyond the perineum and involves some or all of the anal sphincter muscle complex.
  • Fourth-degree:  involves the anal sphincter muscle complex and rectal mucosa.

Management



Following delivery, the vagina and perineum undergo a thorough examination to determine the depth of injury (ie, classification) and bleeding.  Third- and fourth-degree lacerations require digital rectal examination to assess the integrity of the anal sphincter complex.



First-degree lacerations do not typically require surgical repair, but second-, third-, and fourth-degree perineal lacerations require repair to reapproximate the tissue layers, particularly the anal sphincter muscles (third- and fourth-degree lacerations), to minimize the risk for anal incontinence.



Patients who undergo surgical repair and have absent or inadequate neuraxial anesthesia require local anesthetic or a pudendal nerve block (

figure 3
), which anesthetizes most of the perineum and external genitalia.  A pudendal nerve block is performed via a transvaginal injection of a local anesthetic medial to the ischial spine and through the sacrospinous ligament (
figure 4
).  Because extensive lacerations can cause heavy bleeding and there is a propensity for structures (eg, external anal sphincter muscle) to retract, patients with extensive third- and fourth-degree lacerations are transferred from the delivery room to the operating room.



In addition, routine postpartum perineal care is recommended for all patients and includes:



  • Pain management:  Perineal pain is often exacerbated by voiding due to the proximity of the laceration to the urethra.  Patients with uncomplicated perineal lacerations or no lacerations are treated with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, pain-relieving sprays or gels, and sitz baths
  • Perineal hygiene:  Such hygiene involves keeping the vulva and perineal areas clean and dry and wearing loose-fitting clothing.
  • Maintenance of soft stools and prevention of constipation.
  • Avoidance of sex until the 6-week postpartum visit to assess perineal healing


All patients also require monitoring for signs of wound infection (eg, severe pain, fever, purulence), hematoma, and wound dehiscence.  Patients with severe perineal pain, abnormal discharge, and a new perineal bulge or mass require evaluation.

Complications and prognosis



Outcomes depend on the classification of perineal laceration and wound healing.



First-degree lacerations typically heal without intervention.  Second-degree perineal lacerations can cause pain, swelling, and bruising immediately postpartum but do not usually cause long-term sequelae.



Third- and fourth-degree lacerations, which cause anal sphincter injury (

figure 5
), usually cause pain and difficulty with bowel movements postpartum.  Because these lacerations and repairs are more extensive, patients are also at risk for the following complications:



  • Dyspareunia and perineal pain:  most common complication, often associated with a fear of sexual activity due to pain and fear of changes in the appearance or structure of the vaginal introitus.
  • Wound infection and/or wound dehiscence:  typically occurs within days or weeks.
  • Anal incontinence:  the presentation may be soon postpartum, delayed (ie, years after delivery), or intermittent with increasing age due to the gradual atrophy of other compensatory pelvic floor muscles.  Patients typically have incontinence of stool or flatus.  Examination may reveal weakened anal sphincter tone, asymmetric sphincter contraction (anal wink), or palpable defect.  Endoanal ultrasonography reveals disrupted anal sphincter complex.
  • Rectovaginal fistula (
    figure 6
    ):  caused by abnormal healing and rectal mucosa infiltration of the rectovaginal septum.  Typically, fistulas develop gradually over weeks to months and present with a malodorous, tan-brown vaginal discharge (ie, fecal matter).  A dark red, velvety lesion (ie, rectal mucosa) may be seen in the posterior vagina.

Prevention



Although perineal lacerations are often unavoidable (particularly in primiparous patients), certain measures may help reduce their incidence and severity:



  • Controlled delivery of the fetal head at delivery
  • Antenatal perineal massage to increase perineal flexibility
  • Application of warm compresses during the second stage of labor to promote tissue elasticity


Notably, routine episiotomy does not decrease the risk for severe lacerations and increases postpartum morbidity.  If an episiotomy is indicated (eg, fetal distress), a mediolateral episiotomy is preferred to avoid anal sphincter injury (

figure 7
).

Summary



Perineal lacerations commonly occur with vaginal delivery and are classified based on depth and anatomic structures involved.  Management is with surgical repair (except for superficial first-degree lacerations) and postpartum perineal care.  Extensive lacerations, which disrupt the anal sphincter muscles (third-degree) and rectal mucosa (fourth-degree), can lead to long-term complications such as dyspareunia, anal incontinence, and rectovaginal fistula.
